document.masterDocTitle: Notes on Canadian Ablabesmyia Johannsen, with keys to known Nearctic immatures of the genus (Diptera: Chironomidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Notes on Canadian Ablabesmyia Johannsen, with keys to known Nearctic immatures of the genus (Diptera: Chironomidae)

This was the only
Ablabesmyia
common in the bottom samples of Lake Winnipeg. The male, illustrated in
Fig. 9
Dâ€“F, shows a considerable variation in the coloration of the abdominal tergites. Some specimens have a completely dark abdomen. However, they are easily recognizable by means of the wings and the leg coloration. Furthermore, one of the reared specimens is a female with completely dark abdomen.
Pupa (n = 1â€“2 ). Total length 5.95â€“7.69 mm . Exuviae pale grayish brown.

Cephalothorax . Thoracic horn (Fig.G) 632â€“761 Âµm long, 307â€“368 Âµm wide, 2.06â€“2.07 times as long as wide, with apicolateral papilla 0.69â€“0.87 from base. Thoracic comb (Fig. G) consisting of 15â€“21 spines, the longest 55â€“ 60 Âµm.

Abdomen . Tergites with shagreen of multibranched spinulae. LS 1 -seta on VII located at or posterior to midpoint. Anal lobe (Fig. G) 1.07â€“1.30 times as long as wide; 2 outer margin with 15 spinules distad of distal setae and about 25 spinules basad of basal seta.

Head . Antenna as in
Fig. 4
G. Lengths of antennal segments (in Âµm): 558â€“730, 643 ( 105 , see
Fig. 10
); 80 â€“109, 99; 6 â€“9, 8; 3 â€“5, 4. AR 5.36â€“6.86 , 6.01 ( 85 , see
Fig. 10
). Basal antennal segment 40 â€“50, 45 Âµm wide; ring organ 0.60â€“0.64 , 0.62 from base; B 1 84â€“110, 100 Âµm; accessory blade 84 â€“104, 98 Âµm, long. Apical style of second segment 8 â€“11, 9 Âµm long; accessory style 3 â€“5, 4 Âµm long. Mandible 234â€“280, 252 Âµm long. Maxillary palp (
Fig.
5
I) 2 -segmented; basal segment 62 â€“78, 70 Âµm long, 20 â€“24, 22 Âµm wide; apical segment 46 â€“64, 58 Âµm long; 11 â€“14, 12 Âµm wide. Ligula (
Fig. 4
N) 164â€“190, 178 Âµm long; apices of teeth even, median and inner teeth truncate with paler apices. Paraglossa 72 â€“88, 82 Âµm long. Hypopharyngeal pecten with 18 â€“21, 20 teeth.

Abdomen . Procercus 343â€“442, 391 Âµm high; 60 â€“76, 67 Âµm wide at base; 5.08â€“7.02 , 5.87 times as high as wide. Anal setae
1300 â€“1509
, 1379 Âµm long; supraanal seta 345â€“442, 391 Âµm long; supraanal seta/anal setae 0.25â€“ 0.34 , 0.29 . Anal tubules 405â€“527, 469 Âµm long. Posterior parapods
1104 â€“1594
, 1388 Âµm long; with numerous strong spinulae on distal 0.4â€“0.5 ; without any darker claws.
Third instar larva. Head capsule length 0.69â€“0.85 , 0.74 mm ( 21 ). AR 3.87â€“4.84 , 4.32 ( 15 ). Basal antennal segment 312â€“374, 344 Âµm ( 21 ) long.

Second instar larva (n = 2 ). Head capsule length 0.42â€“0.47 mm . AR 3.52â€“3.60 . Basal antennal segment 170â€“ 184 Âµm long. (For distribution among instars of head capsule lengths, AR and length of basal antennal segments see
Fig. 10
.)

Distribution and ecology. The species is known from QuÃ©bec to Saskatchewan and south to California, Texas and Florida (
Roback 1971
: 379 ;
Hudson et al . 1990
: 3 ;
Oliver et al. 1990
: 10 ;
Spies 1999
; Epler 2003 , 2010 ;
Caldwell 2009
;
Ashe & Oâ€™Connor 2009
: 121 ).
Sublette ( 1957 : 381 )
found that
A. annulata
in Lake Texoma, Oklahoma and Texas, were littoral occurring in depths down to 6 m and with a maximum at
2 m .
The unusually blunt teeth of the ligula of
A. annulata
suggests that the species has a specialized method of feeding, compared to other
Ablabesmyia
species.
